As a long-time, local artist, I sometimes feel that the city’s current cultural focus prioritizes artists who fit into narratives of external hardship or underrepresented demographics—often leaving those of us who are older, rooted in Austin, and steadily working in the arts feeling overlooked. While I deeply support diverse representation, this shift can make it harder for local, established artists to feel included or valued in current arts initiatives.

Generally, I attend inexpensive to free events. There are plenty of them. But when I want to see a concert at a major venue, the tickets are generally too expensive. I also find it frustrating that so many non-profit events end up being fundraisers. While I want to help and do make donations, it feels like it’s mostly artists and creatives attending, so basically those who aren’t earning much are giving to our own community because our community is not being supported. Finding free time is also a barrier. It’s hard to earn enough money in this city as a non-salaried worker and also have time to get out for fun. I don’t get out for much of the free events, unless it’s visual arts-related and basically part of my need to network.
Lack of time
